They were learning the rules of a game he was no longer playing. Their ambitions—an internship at Deloitte, a graduate scheme at Barclays—seemed like the quaint preoccupations of a distant, primitive tribe.

Then he saw Leo. He was sitting three rows down and to the left, huddled in on himself as if trying to shrink out of existence. His face was the colour of old parchment, his eyes dark-ringed and bloodshot, darting around the room with the frantic, twitchy energy of a cornered animal. He hadn't seen Alistair yet. He was staring at the lecturer but clearly not hearing a word, trapped in the prison of his own panicked mind. Alistair felt a familiar flicker of pity. Leo looked so messy, so loud, his terror a chaotic broadcast that only Alistair could receive. The lecture ended. The students began to pack their bags, the low hum of chatter filling the room. Leo was one of the first to bolt, shoving his laptop into his bag and scrambling for the aisle. Alistair, moving with his new, unhurried grace, packed his own things and timed his exit to intercept him near the doors.

"Leo," he said. His voice was calm, level, friendly. The single word hit Leo like a physical blow. He froze, his back to Alistair, his shoulders hitched up to his ears. Slowly, he turned. His face was a mask of raw horror. His eyes were wide, his mouth a thin, bloodless line. He looked at Alistair as if he were seeing a ghost. "Alright?" Alistair asked, his expression one of mild, friendly concern. He tilted his head slightly. "You look rough, mate. Everything okay?" The question was a masterpiece of casual cruelty. It was a normal question, the most normal question in the world, and it was utterly, terrifyingly insane. Leo's mouth opened, but no sound came out. He stared, his mind screaming, at the placid, concerned face of his friend, the face of the monster. He looked at the clean hands, the tidy jumper, the total absence of any mark of the previous night's horror. And he knew, with a certainty that chilled him to the marrow, that Alistair was not just in control. He was enjoying this. This performance. This quiet, sadistic game. With a choked sob, Leo turned and fled, pushing his way blindly through the crowd of students, a man running for his life in a world that couldn't see the predator walking calmly behind him.

Alistair watched Leo disappear into the throng, a frantic blur of panicked motion. He didn't feel a flicker of triumph, only a quiet, analytical curiosity. It was like observing a chemical reaction: introduce a catalyst of truth into Leo’s unstable compound of mundane anxieties, and the result was this predictable, chaotic fizzing. A small, almost imperceptible sigh escaped Alistair’s lips. It was a shame. He had genuinely thought, for a moment, that Leo might understand. That he might see the beauty in the silence, the elegant solution Alistair had discovered. But Leo was still part of the noise, a slave to it, his fear just another discordant shriek in the grand, pointless symphony. Alistair turned and walked in the opposite direction, toward the student union building, his pace measured and calm.

He bought a black coffee from a bored-looking girl with a nose ring and found a seat by a large window overlooking the main campus square. He watched the students pass by, their faces a mixture of stress, excitement, and performative nonchalance. They moved in chattering groups, their conversations a meaningless torrent of gossip about parties, complaints about deadlines, and feverish speculation about graduate schemes. Alistair sipped his coffee, the bitter taste grounding him. He felt like a biologist looking at a petri dish teeming with frantic, short-lived organisms, each convinced of its own cosmic importance. He had been one of them just twenty-four hours ago, and the thought was so bizarre, so alien, that it was like trying to recall a dream. The hunger that had driven him to sit amongst them, feigning interest, was gone. He no longer needed their approval or their company. He was a higher form of life now, self-sustaining and serene.

The memory of the alleyway surfaced, not as a traumatic flashback, but as a cool, clear thought, like recalling a theorem he had finally proven. He remembered the feeling of the man's surprising fragility, the wet finality of his last breath, the overwhelming, coppery richness of the act that followed. There was no horror in the memory, no guilt. There was only a profound sense of rightness. It had been a transaction. The man had possessed something vital, something real, but had no use for it. He was a ghost, invisible, his life force a guttering candle in the wind. Alistair had simply been the wind. He had taken that flickering, wasted energy and absorbed it, converting it into this glorious, solid peace. It wasn't murder; it was recycling. It was the most logical, the most efficient, the most profoundly tidy act of his entire life.

He finished his coffee and pulled out his phone. He scrolled to his contacts and paused on Leo’s name. He could feel Leo's terror as a palpable thing, a frantic vibration across town. He imagined his friend locked in his room, replaying the night, replaying their conversation in the lecture hall, his mind a runaway train of fear. The impulse to reach out was not born of malice, not exactly. It was more akin to a scientist wanting to poke his experiment to observe the results. It was about control. It was about reminding Leo of the new, unshakeable order of things. He typed a short, simple message, his thumb moving with placid precision. *Did you get the slides from the Risk Mitigation lecture? My laptop froze halfway through.* He read the message over once. It was perfect. It was normal. It was a request from a friend, a demand for a response, a tiny, mundane hook that would drag Leo right back to the edge of the abyss and force him to look down. He pressed send. The message disappeared into the ether, a silent, digital shiv aimed directly at his friend's soul.

Leo made it back to his room and slammed the door, ramming the flimsy lock into place. The sound echoed the frantic hammering of his own heart. He paced the cramped space, a caged animal in a den of his own making. Clothes were strewn on the floor, empty mugs and textbooks formed precarious towers on his desk, and the air was thick with the scent of stale air and unwashed everything. This mess, his natural habitat, usually felt comfortable, lived-in. Now it felt like a physical manifestation of his unravelling mind. He was a shipwreck, and his room was the debris field. He couldn't think. He could only feel. The image of Alistair's calm, friendly face in the lecture hall was seared onto the inside of his eyelids. It was the friendly mask on a skull, a polite smile on the face of utter oblivion.

His phone, lying face down on his desk, buzzed. The sound, small and innocuous, made Leo cry out, a sharp, strangled yelp of pure terror. He froze, staring at the black rectangle as if it were a venomous insect. He knew who it was. He knew it with a certainty that was as absolute and terrifying as the knowledge of his own mortality. It was him. Reaching out. Proving he could. Proving that there was no escape, no corner of Leo’s life that he couldn't now touch and contaminate. He wanted to throw the phone against the wall, to smash it to pieces, to silence it forever. But he couldn't. He was paralyzed by the knowledge that ignoring it was as much of an answer as replying. Slowly, his hand trembling so badly he could barely control it, he reached out and turned the phone over. The screen lit up, displaying the message. *Did you get the slides from the Risk Mitigation lecture? My laptop froze halfway through.* The sheer, devastating banality of it stole the air from his lungs. It wasn't a threat. It wasn't a confession. It was a piece of normal life, weaponized. It was a question about a lecture he hadn't heard, from a man who had devoured another human being less than a day ago. It was a leash, and Alistair was giving it a gentle, almost playful, tug.

Leo stared at the message, the innocuous words forming a cage around him. The blinking cursor in the reply field pulsed like a beacon in a storm, demanding an answer, a performance. He had to respond. Silence was an answer in itself, a loud, screaming confession of his terror. To survive, he had to play Alistair’s game. He had to pretend he was still a student, still a friend, still a resident of the world where the biggest problem was a frozen laptop. His thumb hovered over the virtual keyboard, shaking. He typed, deleted, typed again, each word a potential landmine. *'No, sorry'* felt too curt, too dismissive. *'Wasn’t paying attention, mate'* felt too honest, an invitation for the question he couldn't answer: *Why?* He was trying to craft a lie so perfect, so beige, so utterly devoid of meaning that it would slide harmlessly into the conversation, but every combination of letters felt heavy with the unspoken truth, saturated with his fear. The simple act of communication, the basic currency of his social life, had become an exercise in high-stakes diplomacy with a terrorist state of one. Finally, sucking in a ragged breath, he typed the most neutral, empty phrase he could conjure: *‘Sorry, missed them too.’* He pressed send. The message vanished from his screen, a white flag of surrender sent across enemy lines. He had done it. He had spoken to the monster in its own language, the language of suffocating normality. The relief was immediately replaced by a fresh wave of self-loathing and a chilling sense of complicity.

Alistair sat by the window in the student union, the grey light bathing his placid features. His phone chimed softly, and he picked it up without haste. He read Leo's reply, and the barest hint of a smile touched the corners of his mouth. It was a perfect response. So weak, so compliant, so terrified. Leo was trying to build a wall of normality, but he had used Alistair’s own bricks to do it. The message wasn’t just an answer to a question; it was an acceptance of the new terms and conditions of their relationship. Alistair was the author of reality now, and Leo had just agreed to read from the script. This feeling was different from the raw, primal satisfaction of the previous night. That had been a raging fire, a glorious inferno of consumption. This was a slow-burning ember, a quiet, sustained warmth of absolute control. It was the pleasure of the spider feeling the first, faint tremor of a fly caught on the outer edge of its web. He typed a final message, a parting gift of dread. *‘No worries. See you at the King’s Head later? Usual time?’* He sent it and put the phone away without waiting for a reply. He had no doubt Leo would be there.

The library was a hushed cathedral of stress. Students were hunched over laptops, their faces illuminated by the blueish glow of screens, their expressions ranging from panicked to catatonic. Alistair found an empty carrel on the third floor, a quiet corner overlooking the main reading room below. He didn't open a book. He didn't turn on his laptop. He simply sat and watched. Before, this place had been an extension of his own inadequacy, each studious individual a judgment on his lack of focus and ambition. Now, he saw it with a startling new clarity. It was a farm. It was a well-stocked pantry. He looked down at the herds of them, grazing on information, fattening themselves on knowledge for a future that seemed, to him, entirely hypothetical. He saw them not as people, but as systems of energy. He saw the anxious, fidgeting boy who was probably cramming for a resit, his life force a frantic, crackling spark. He saw the confident, popular girl holding court at a large table, her vitality a bright, steady flame. He saw the solitary figures in the corners, the ones who blended into the background, their signals faint, almost invisible. Just like the man in the alley. The thought came to him, unbidden and with a cool, crystalline logic: the hunger would return. It was a biological certainty. This place, this whole university, was a buffet of infinite possibility. The realisation brought with it no fear or excitement, only a profound and calming sense of security. He would never starve again.

Leo read the second text while sitting on the edge of his bed, and for a moment he thought he would be sick. *See you at the King’s Head later? Usual time?* It was a summons. A command dressed up as a friendly invitation. It was Alistair demonstrating, with chilling nonchalance, that the horror of last night had not ruptured their routine; it had merely been incorporated into it. The pub, their pub, a place of shared jokes and complaints about coursework, was now to be the stage for the next act of this waking nightmare. To refuse would be an act of defiance, a tearing of the script, and Leo could not begin to imagine the consequences of that. To go would be to willingly walk back into the spider's web, to sit across a table from the thing that had worn his friend's face and pretend to enjoy a pint of lukewarm lager. His mind screamed at him to run, to pack a bag and get on the first train to anywhere, to disappear. But Alistair's calm, predatory patience seemed to reach across the town and hold him in place. Disappearing would be an admission of guilt, a panicked flight that would only pique the interest of the authorities Alistair so cleverly avoided. He was trapped not by walls or bars, but by the suffocating web of the mundane. He had to go. He had to sit there, smile, and pretend that everything was fine, while the ghost of a man he’d never met sat between them.

The hours leading up to eight o'clock were a new kind of torture for Leo. He tried to distract himself, putting on music that was just noise, opening a textbook whose words swam before his eyes like meaningless black insects. Every passing minute was a tick of the countdown clock to his own damnation. Getting ready felt like preparing for his own execution. He pulled on a hoodie that felt like a shroud and trainers that felt like lead weights. The walk to The King's Head, a ten-minute route he could have navigated blindfolded, felt like a journey into a foreign and hostile territory. Every cheerful light in a window, every burst of laughter from a passing group of students, was a jeer from a world he had been unceremoniously evicted from. He was a ghost walking to his own wake, and the guest of honour was the man who had killed him.

He paused outside the pub, the familiar stained-glass windows glowing like jewels in the dark. The low thrum of music and the cacophony of a hundred conversations washed over him, a wave of life so normal it was physically painful. He could turn around. He could run, get on a bus, and just leave. But the image of Alistair’s calm, questioning face materialized in his mind. He knew, with a certainty that was now lodged permanently in his gut, that running would solve nothing. It would just be a different kind of trap, a different kind of performance. Taking a breath that felt like swallowing sand, he pushed the heavy oak door open and stepped inside. The wall of warm, beer-scented air hit him, thick with the smell of life being lived. And he saw him. Alistair was sitting at their usual table in the corner, nursing a pint, looking for all the world like he had been there for hours. He wasn't scanning the crowd, wasn't looking for Leo. He was staring into the middle distance with a faint, pleasant smile, a man utterly at peace with himself.

Leo’s feet moved of their own accord, carrying him across the sticky floor towards the table. The journey of twenty feet felt like crossing a vast, empty desert. Alistair looked up as he approached, and his smile broadened, becoming one of genuine, uncomplicated warmth. It was the most monstrous thing Leo had ever seen. “Alright, mate,” Alistair said, his voice perfectly normal, perfectly friendly, cutting through the pub's din. “Was beginning to think you’d bailed on me.” He gestured to the pint of lager sitting opposite him, a glistening, amber beacon of horror. “Got you one. Hope that’s okay.” It wasn’t a question. It was a statement of fact, an assertion of a shared routine that Alistair had decided would continue, unbroken. Leo slid onto the bench, the worn leather cool against his legs. He couldn't speak, so he just nodded, his throat a tight knot of unshed screams.

“You really look like you’ve been dragged through a hedge backwards,” Alistair observed, taking a slow sip of his beer. He studied Leo over the rim of his glass, his eyes full of a warm, clinical concern. “Everything good at home? You’re not letting the pressure of final year get to you, are you?” The questions were so mundane, so perfectly pitched to their usual conversational repertoire, that for a split second, Leo’s terror-addled brain almost believed them. He almost thought he could answer normally, could complain about his dissertation or his housemates, and the last twenty-four hours would evaporate like a bad dream. But then he met Alistair’s eyes, and he saw the stillness there, the deep, sated calm of the predator, and the illusion shattered. He saw the gleam of the game. “Just… tired,” Leo managed to croak, the words feeling like shards of glass in his throat. He wrapped his shaking hands around his own pint, the cold, damp glass the only solid thing in his dissolving world.

He forced himself to take a drink, the familiar taste of the cheap lager turning to ash in his mouth. He focused on the television above the bar, where a football match was playing on mute, the tiny figures chasing a ball with a frantic, pointless energy that mirrored the chaos in his own head. He could feel Alistair's gaze on him, patient and amused. “You know, I feel the opposite,” Alistair said conversationally, placing his glass down with a soft click. “I feel… rested. Clear. Like I finally got rid of something that was weighing me down. It’s amazing what a change of diet can do for you.” The words, each one a perfectly polished stone of malice, dropped into the space between them. Leo’s head snapped towards him, his eyes wide with disbelief at the sheer, brazen audacity of the remark. Alistair simply held his gaze, his expression one of complete, guileless sincerity, as if he were genuinely sharing a new health tip he had discovered.

Leaning forward slightly, Alistair lowered his voice, forcing Leo to lean in to hear him over a nearby burst of laughter. The intimacy of the gesture was a violation. “The problem with our generation, Leo, is that we’re starving. We’re fed all this stuff—social media, career goals, endless noise—but none of it has any substance. It’s like eating styrofoam. You chew and you chew, but you’re always empty.” He paused, his eyes twinkling with a dark, didactic light. “You just have to find something with real substance. Something… organic. Once you do, everything else just becomes quiet. You understand what I’m saying, don’t you?” It wasn’t a question. It was a coronation. Alistair was anointing himself king of this new, silent world, and he was explaining the tenets of his reign to his first, terrified subject. Leo felt a tremor run through his entire body. He wasn't just a witness anymore. He was a student, and this was his first lesson.

Finally, Alistair drained his glass and stood up, stretching lazily as if he’d just woken from a pleasant nap. The movement was fluid, confident, the movement of a man entirely comfortable in his own body. Leo remained frozen on the bench, a statue carved from fear. “Right, I’m making a move,” Alistair said brightly, pulling on his jacket. “Things to do tomorrow. The world doesn’t stop, eh?” He reached out and clapped Leo firmly on the shoulder, a gesture of camaraderie that felt like a branding iron. Leo flinched so violently he nearly knocked his pint over. Alistair’s smile didn’t falter. “Take it easy, mate. And get some sleep. You look like death.” With a final, cheerful nod, he turned and walked away, weaving effortlessly through the crowd and out of the door, vanishing back into the night that he now owned. Leo was left alone at the table, the untouched pint sweating in front of him, the cold spot on his shoulder a mark of ownership, a promise of horrors yet to come. The noise of the pub rushed back in, but it couldn't touch him. He was trapped in a bubble of perfect, terrifying silence.

## Chapter 5

Leo remained on the bench long after Alistair had gone, a piece of human driftwood left by a receding, toxic tide. The noise of the pub, which had been a dull roar at the edge of his consciousness, rushed back in with a vengeance. He heard the sharp crack of a pool cue hitting a ball, a woman’s shrieking laughter, the thumping bassline of a song he vaguely recognised from a life he no longer lived. Every sound was a tiny, sharp-edged piece of a world he could see and hear but no longer touch. It was a party behind a soundproof wall of glass, and he was on the wrong side. He looked at the two pint glasses on the table: his own, nearly full and sweating condensation, and Alistair’s, empty, clean, and finished. It was a perfect metaphor. Alistair consumed, and Leo was left to drown. He eventually stood, his limbs stiff and uncooperative, and walked out of the pub without a backward glance, leaving the full pint on the table like an offering to a malevolent god.

The days that followed dissolved into a single, seamless stretch of grey dread. Leo stopped going to lectures. The thought of sitting in a room with hundreds of people, of potentially seeing Alistair’s placid, smiling face, was more than he could bear. He remained in his room, the curtains drawn, the door locked. The mess, once a simple feature of his student life, began to grow with a life of its own, a creeping fungus of neglect. Dirty plates and mugs colonized his desk, and a mountain of clothes grew in the corner, exuding a faint, sour smell. He lived on dry cereal and toast, his body fuelled by the bare minimum required to sustain the frantic, looping hamster wheel of his thoughts. He was haunted. Alistair’s voice was a constant whisper in the silence of the room, calmly explaining his philosophy of consumption, his dark eyes gleaming with the light of a terrible new faith. His phone became an object of pure terror. Every time it lay silent, he imagined Alistair was watching him, waiting. Every time it buzzed with a message from his mother or a notification from a sports app, his heart seized in a violent, painful spasm of panic, a pavlovian response to a horror that was now a permanent part of his nervous system.

While Leo disintegrated, Alistair flourished. The deep, resonant peace held, and with his mind finally free from the static of his own dissatisfaction, his intellect became a sharp, coolly effective tool. In seminars, he was no longer the ghost at the feast but a star contributor. He spoke with a newfound, articulate confidence, dissecting complex theories of market ethics and corporate responsibility with a detached brilliance that unnerved his peers and impressed his tutors. He delivered a presentation on risk management that was so sharp, so insightful, and so ruthlessly logical that his professor asked him to consider applying for a postgraduate degree. He was a model of academic success. His life outside the university was a portrait of quiet respectability. He was always on time with his rent, his room was immaculate, and he even engaged in brief, polite conversations with Carol in the hallway, discussing the weather and the council’s inconsistent recycling schedule with a sincerity that she found utterly charming. He was building his camouflage, brick by perfect, beige brick, constructing a fortress of normality so absolute that no one would ever think to look inside.

The hunger did not return as a gnawing void, but as a subtle shift in taste, a returning restlessness. The peace, he discovered, was not a permanent state but a finite resource, a charge that slowly depleted. It was a Wednesday afternoon in the campus canteen. Alistair sat with a tray bearing a slice of lasagne, a wilting side salad, and a bottle of water. He took a bite of the lasagne. The texture was mushy, the flavour a homogenous, synthetic tang of tomato paste and cheap cheese. It was flavourless fuel, the styrofoam he had described to Leo. He felt a faint, old echo of the ache in his gut, not the desperate emptiness of before, but a low, humming impatience. The world of Pot Noodles and sad beige sandwiches was no longer just bland; it was an insult. He looked around the crowded canteen at the hundreds of students, all talking and laughing and eating, consuming their own bland fuel, and he felt a profound sense of alienation, but this time it was tinged with a cool, predatory superiority. They were cattle, grazing in a concrete field, and he was the only wolf in the county.

He began to spend his afternoons in the university library again, but his purpose had changed. He would find a carrel on an upper floor that offered a panoramic view of the main reading areas below and he would simply watch. It was an exercise in data collection. He wasn't looking for friends or rivals; he was sourcing a product. He categorised the students in his mind. There were the 'Alphas'—the loud, confident, socially networked ones who moved in large, bright herds. Too visible, too much risk, their absence would create a noticeable tear in the social fabric. Then there were the 'Betas'—the vast, anonymous majority, the backbone of the student body, who moved in smaller, tighter packs. Still too connected, their disappearance would trigger alarms within their social sub-systems. And then there were the 'Omegas'. The forgotten ones. The solitary figures who sat alone, who walked the corridors with their eyes down, who ate their lunch with a book for a companion. They were the ghosts, just as he had once been. Their signals were faint, their connections to the network tenuous. They were the low-risk, high-yield targets. They were the ones nobody would miss, or at least, not for a very long time.

His attention, over several days, began to fixate on one. A postgraduate history student from overseas, a quiet, bird-like girl named Anja. He didn't know her name at first; he just knew her patterns. She was always in the same section of the library, the quietest corner of the top floor, surrounded by dusty tomes on medieval Europe. She never spoke to anyone, and no one ever spoke to her. She wore the same dark grey coat every day, a shade that seemed designed to help her fade into the brutalist concrete architecture of the library. Alistair watched her come and go, her movements as predictable and precise as a clock. He saw the faint, persistent anxiety in her eyes, the way she clutched her books to her chest like a shield. She was profoundly, deeply alone, an island of quiet despair in a sea of youthful exuberance. The low, humming impatience in Alistair’s gut began to sharpen, to focus. It was the faint, biological signal in a world of concrete and glass, the flicker of warmth in the cold, sterile air of the library. He felt the hunger stir, not as a desperate craving, but as a calm, logical, and entirely necessary impulse. He closed his textbook on International Business Law, the decision made, the next step in the process clarified. The sated peace had been pleasant, but it was the quiet thrill of the hunt, he now realised, that made him feel truly, terrifyingly alive.

Alistair began his project with the dispassionate methodology of a research student. The university's online portal, a tool designed for collaboration and academic inquiry, became his primary instrument of surveillance. A few clicks, cross-referencing module codes and postgraduate directories, yielded a name: Anja Nowak. History MA. Her profile picture was a low-resolution, awkward selfie taken against a plain wall, her expression timid, her eyes avoiding the camera. She had no listed society memberships, no presence on the university's social forums. She was a digital ghost, a sparse collection of data points that confirmed her profound isolation. He wasn't prying into a life; he was assessing a target profile, collating information, and calculating risk. He felt the same cool, intellectual satisfaction he had once been told he should derive from analysing a balance sheet.

The first point of contact was engineered with surgical precision. He waited in the dusty stacks of the medieval history section, a place so silent the rustle of a turning page sounded like a breaking wave. When Anja reached for a heavy, leather-bound book on an upper shelf, he stepped out from behind a nearby bay as if he had been browsing there all along. "Here, allow me," he said, his voice a low, friendly murmur. He was taller than her, and easily retrieved the tome. She flinched at his sudden appearance, her body recoiling as if from a physical blow, clutching her bag to her chest. He held the book out to her, taking a small, deliberate step back to give her space, his expression one of polite, apologetic helpfulness. "Sorry, didn't mean to startle you. It's a tomb up here, isn't it?" Her eyes, a pale, watery blue, darted from his face to the book and back again. She gave a jerky, barely perceptible nod, accepting the heavy volume with trembling hands. "Thank you," she whispered, the words so quiet they were almost lost in the profound silence. He gave her a small, reassuring smile and then simply turned and walked away, not waiting for any further interaction. The test was complete. The data was confirmed. She was terrified of contact, but too polite and too timid to register it as a threat. She was perfect.

While Alistair was refining his methods, Leo was losing his. His room had become a biohazard, a fetid swamp of his own decaying psyche. The world outside his drawn curtains ceased to exist. His phone, which he now kept wrapped in a t-shirt at the bottom of his laundry pile to muffle its terrifying buzz, rang one afternoon with a relentless, insistent cheerfulness. It was his mother. He stared at the vibrating lump of fabric for a full minute before his fear of her worry briefly eclipsed his fear of everything else. He answered, his voice a dry, unused croak. "Leo? Darling? Is everything alright? I haven't heard from you in a week." Her voice, so full of normal, maternal concern, was a sound from another planet. "I'm fine, Mum," he lied, the words tasting like poison. "Just… swamped. Dissertation." He listened as she talked about her book club, his father's golf handicap, the neighbour's new puppy. Every mundane detail was a fresh stab of grief for the world he had lost. "Are you eating properly, love? You sound peaky." He looked at the half-eaten packet of stale biscuits on his bedside table. "Eating like a king, Mum," he rasped, ending the call as quickly as he could. He tossed the phone back into the laundry pile and curled into a ball on his bed, pulling the duvet over his head. But there was no escape. In the darkness, Alistair’s calm, smiling face was waiting for him, asking if he wanted another pint.

Alistair's fieldwork began. For three consecutive evenings, he followed Anja from the library. His route was never direct; he would take parallel streets, observing from a distance, using shop windows as mirrors, melting into the shadows of bus stops. He was a ghost in her wake. He noted her path with the analytical eye of a logistician. She lived in a block of postgraduate flats on the far side of town, a twenty-minute walk that took her away from the main, well-lit thoroughfares and down a series of quiet, residential Victorian streets. On the final stretch, she took a shortcut. It was a narrow, unlit footpath that ran between the back gardens of two rows of houses, connecting one road to the next. It was fenced on both sides with high, ivy-covered wood, had no overlooking windows, and was bookended by pools of deep shadow, far from the nearest streetlights. Alistair stood at the entrance to the path after she had passed through, the scent of damp earth and decaying leaves filling his nostrils. It was not a squalid, regrettable alleyway like the last one. It was tidy. It was secluded. It was efficient. He had found his venue.

The execution of the plan required a specific confluence of factors: timing, weather, opportunity. He found it on a Thursday evening, a steady, miserable drizzle descending on Guildford, emptying the streets of casual walkers. He positioned himself by the library exit, holding a book, his expression one of mild frustration as if waiting for a friend who was late. When Anja emerged, pulling the hood of her grey coat up over her head, he "noticed" her and fell into step beside her, his smile disarmingly sheepish. "Anja, right? Sorry, we met in the stacks the other day. Alistair." He gestured vaguely with the hand not holding his book. "This rain is miserable, isn't it?" He scrolled back, watching Sean’s journey in reverse, from the canals of Amsterdam to the museums of Paris, until he reached the final, fateful posts from England.

While Leo was resurrecting the dead online, Alistair was demonstrating the art of control in a brightly lit seminar room. The topic was a case study on corporate social responsibility, and Alistair, leaning back in his chair, was effortlessly deconstructing the naive arguments of his peers. He spoke with a calm, chilling precision about externalities, acceptable losses, and the dispassionate removal of inefficient assets for the greater health of the system. He was not just answering the professor’s questions; he was reframing the entire debate, his logic so sharp and so devoid of sentiment that it silenced the room. He felt the familiar, pleasant warmth of intellectual dominance. His gaze drifted across the faces of his classmates, categorising them with the detached eye of a farmer surveying his livestock. He saw the flicker of admiration in some, the glint of competitive envy in others. He even saw Leo, sitting near the back, head down, scribbling in a textbook. The sight brought a faint, paternal smile to his lips. The boy was learning his place. Broken, quiet, and tidy. The world was in its correct and proper order.

Leo’s breakthrough came late in the afternoon. He had scrolled to the very end of Sean Riley’s digital life. The last post was a photograph, taken just a day before he was due to fly home. It was a simple, cheerful shot: a pint of dark ale resting on a wooden table, condensation beading on the glass. The caption read, "Last pint in Blighty! Guildford's a tidy little spot. Onwards tomorrow." The word ‘tidy’ made the hair on Leo’s arms stand up. But it was the details in the photograph that seized his attention. The table was etched with years of use, and in the corner of the frame, resting next to the pint, was a beer mat. It was dark green, and emblazoned on it in gold was the snarling head of a lion. Leo’s heart hammered in his chest. It was not the logo of the King’s Head. It was the crest of The Lion’s Paw, a quiet, older pub near the river, a place known for its real ale and its distinct lack of students.

That evening, Leo stood across the street from The Lion's Paw, a dark shape huddled in the deeper shadows of a shop doorway. The pub glowed with a warm, welcoming light, patrons drifting in and out, their laughter carrying on the cold night air. This was it. This was the second crime scene. Alistair hadn't taken Sean to their usual haunt; he had met him on his own territory. Had he sat with him, charmed him with conversation, pretended to be a friendly local showing a tourist a proper English pub? The pattern was becoming clearer. Alistair was not a random force of nature. He was a creature of habit, a predator with specific hunting grounds, each one chosen for a specific type of prey. The alleyway for the invisible man; this quiet, respectable pub for the trusting tourist. He, Leo, had been trying to understand the monster. He now realised his mistake. To catch the monster, he had to understand his victims. He was not just chasing Alistair anymore. He was following the ghosts of the people Alistair had erased, and for the first time, he felt they were leading him down a path the monster didn't even know existed.

Stepping out of the shadows, Leo crossed the street, the cheerful light of The Lion's Paw pulling him in like a moth to a flame he knew was fatal. The act of pushing open the pub's heavy, dark-wood door was a declaration of war he was not sure he could survive. The air inside was warm and thick, smelling of old beer, woodsmoke from a crackling fireplace, and the faint, sweet scent of pipe tobacco. It was a world away from the student-filled chaos of The King’s Head. Here, the clientele was older, their conversations a low, comfortable murmur. Men with grey in their beards sat reading newspapers at the bar, and couples shared quiet words in high-backed booths. It was a place of settled, comfortable lives, and Leo’s presence, young and taut with a silent, screaming tension, felt like a tear in the fabric of its peace.

He forced his legs to carry him to the bar, his gaze sweeping the room, trying to picture Sean Riley sitting here, full of life and easy charm, unaware that he was in the company of the plague. The bartender was a man in his late fifties, with a weary, seen-it-all face and forearms like knotted ropes. He polished a glass with a slow, methodical rhythm, his eyes briefly flicking up to register Leo, a flicker of surprise in their depths. Leo waited, letting the man finish his task, trying to project an air of casual patience he was a million miles from feeling. "Evening," the bartender grunted, his voice a low gravel. "What can I get you?" This was the moment. The performance had to be perfect. "Just a pint of ale, please," Leo said, his voice steadier than he expected. "Whatever you recommend." As the bartender turned to pull the pint, Leo took out his phone. "Actually," he began, forcing a note of friendly uncertainty into his voice. "This is going to sound strange. A mate of mine, from Australia, told me to come here. Said it was the best pint in Guildford. He sent me a picture." He slid the phone across the polished bar, Sean Riley's last Instagram post glowing on the screen.

The bartender placed the full pint on the bar and glanced down at the phone, his expression unchanging. He squinted at the screen for a moment, his gaze lingering on the photo of the beer, the table, the distinctive green beer mat. Leo held his breath. "Aye, that's one of ours," the man said, nodding slowly. "Looks like the Cromwell. Good choice." He pushed the phone back towards Leo, his face a mask of professional indifference. Leo’s heart sank. It was a dead end. He had been a fool to think this would work. But as he reached for his phone, the bartender paused, a flicker of memory crossing his weary features. "An Aussie, you said? Young lad? Longish hair, big smile?" Leo’s head snapped up, his eyes wide. He nodded, unable to speak. "Yeah, I remember him," the bartender said, a faint, almost fond smile touching his lips. "He was in a few weeks back. Nice kid. Full of questions. Sat right there at the end of the bar for a couple of hours." He gestured with his chin towards the far corner. "Funny thing was," he continued, picking up another glass to polish, "he was talking to another young fella. A student, by the sounds of it. Well-spoken, tidy-looking lad. Didn't think it was one of your lot's kind of place, but they seemed to be getting on like a house on fire."

While Leo was exhuming ghosts in a quiet pub, Alistair was taking a late afternoon walk through the botanical gardens. The manicured flowerbeds and neatly labelled trees soothed him, their order a reflection of his own internal state. He had reasserted control, tidied the mess, and the world was once again a place of predictable systems and manageable variables. But as he walked, his senses, sharpened by his new state of being, were constantly, passively collecting data. He was browsing. His gaze drifted over a group of laughing students on a lawn, dismissing them as too loud, too connected. His eyes fell on an elderly couple walking hand-in-hand, their life-force a gentle, fading glow that held no interest for him. Then he saw him. Working in a secluded bed of rhododendrons, away from the main path, was one of the university's groundskeepers. The man was in his late forties, powerfully built, his movements economical and strong as he dug at the stubborn earth. He worked alone, his face set in a permanent, brooding mask, ignoring the students who passed by. He was a piece of the campus furniture, as unremarkable and as invisible as a lamppost. But he was not weak. He was not a ghost like Mac, or a trusting sheep like Sean. He was a different category of prey entirely. The thought was intriguing. To hunt and consume such a man would not just be an act of sating hunger; it would be an act of ultimate dominance. A faint, anticipatory smile touched Alistair’s lips. The connoisseur had just found a new, challenging vintage he was eager to sample.

Leo stumbled out of The Lion’s Paw into the cold night, his mind reeling. *Well-spoken, tidy-looking lad.* The bartender's words were a second voice on a recording, a corroborating witness from beyond the grave. Alistair had been there. He had sat at that bar, charming a young man full of life, buying him pints, gaining his trust, all the while knowing he was going to extinguish him. The sheer, cold-blooded premeditation of it was a new dimension of horror. This was Alistair’s art form: the careful, patient seduction of his victims, the bespoke tailoring of his approach to fit their specific profile. He had used kindness to trap the lonely, and camaraderie to disarm the trusting. The walk back to his room was a fugue state, the world outside a distant, meaningless blur. He held the new information in his mind like a holy relic, a piece of truth so pure and so terrible it felt like it might burn him from the inside out.

He burst into his room, locking the door behind him, and went straight to the heavy book on his desk. He opened it to the pages dedicated to Sean Riley. Beneath the date and the victim’s name, he began to write, his pencil moving with a fierce, controlled precision. *Location of final contact confirmed: The Lion’s Paw. Witness (bartender) confirms V2 was in conversation with subject matching A’s description. Method: Ingratiation. A posed as a friendly local, exploiting V2’s status as a tourist to establish trust in a non-student environment. Pattern established: A alters hunting ground and grooming method based on target profile.* The words filled the margin, a cold, analytical deconstruction of a monstrous act. The book was no longer just a memorial. It was an investigation file, a profile of a predator more cunning, more adaptable, and more intelligent than he had ever imagined. Staring at the evidence he had gathered on Mac and Sean, a chilling thought struck him. He had uncovered the methodology for the ghosts, for the ones who had vanished without a trace. But what about Anja? She was different. She had been a threat. Alistair’s hunt for her must have been different, too. It would not have been a casual grooming. It would have been a targeted elimination. Understanding how Alistair had hunted her would be the key. And as that thought landed, a new, terrifying idea began to form in the deepest, coldest corner of his mind. He couldn’t go to the police. He couldn’t reason with the monster. To stop a hunter who plans his kills with such meticulous care, you cannot simply be a witness. You have to build a trap.
